Idm API Schema Types

This is the main index XML Schema document for the Rackspace Identity Management API.

Entities related to backwards compatible auth.

Entities related to backwards compatible auth endpoints.

Entities related to IdM permissions.

Entities related to IdM roles.

Entities related to API version details.

User entities.

Client entities.

Customer entities.

Defines credentials used to obtain an OAuth token.

Password entities.

All fault types.

End user password recovery request..

Credentials

This schema file defines entities credentials used to obtained a token from the authentication service.

Credentials used to obtain an auth token.

Nast Credentials.

Mosso Credentials.

The API key.

The name of the user authenticated.

Nast Id used to identify the user.

Mosso account used to identify the user.

An Auth Token.

The service catalog.

A combination of the token and the service catalog. This is returned when a user authenticates.

BaseUrls and Endpoints

The service catalog contains a list of all regional and global endpoints available to a user. The endpoints are sorted by service type.

A list of services.

A list of endpoints.

The service name.

The airport code of the region where the endpoint lives.

If true, then the endpoint will be selected automatically in V1.0 of the Auth API.

The publically accessible service URL.

A service URL, accessible only within the Rackspace Cloud.

A service URL used for administration. This may expose additional functionality not found in the public and internal URL.

A list of base URLs.

A base URLs.

A refrence to a base URL.

A list of base URL refrences.

An ID uniquely identifying the base URL.

What type of user information should be appended to this baseURL to form a complete endpoint.

The base URL's service name.

The URL's region.

The public base URL.

The internal version of the public base URL.

The admin base URL.

If true the baseURL is automatically added to new accounts.

An ID uniquely identifying the base URL.

A hyperlink refrence to the base URL.

If true, then the refred to base URL is used in version 1.0 of the Auth service.

An authRequest can be made with various user/account names. The UserType signifies what kind of account is being used to log in.

Cloud username. This is the same as the unique user id in the UserType.

Nast account number. This is the same as a nastId in the UserType.

Mosso account number. This is the same as mossoId in the UserType.

Tokens

This schema file defines entities related to tokens.

Entities related users.

Entities related to clients.

Entities related to permissions.

The data returned for a successful authentication.

The data required for authentication.

An authentication Token.

The token id.

A number of seconds until the token expires.

An access token.

A refresh token.

The user associated with the token.

A client associated with the token.

The OAuth grant type.

The client Id.

The client secret.

The user's username.

The user's password.

The refresh token Id.

The OAuth grant type api_credentials.

The OAuth grant type assertion.

The OAuth grant type authorization_code.

The OAuth grant type none.

The OAuth grant type password.

The OAuth grant type refresh_token.

Users

This schema file defines entities related to a user.

A rackspace user's credentials.

A rackspace user's api key.

A rackspace user's password.

A rackspace user.

A list of rackspace users.

A rackspace user's secret question and answer.

The user's new password.

The user's current password.

A user's secret question.

The answer to the user's secret question.

A user's password.

A user's api key.

A list of roles the user belongs to.

The unique username of the user.

The customerId of the customer that the user is associated with.

The customer inum of the customer that the user is associated with.

The user's email address.

A unique rackspace personId for the user.

The user's first name.

The user's middle name.

The user's last name.

The user's display name.

The user's preferred language.

The user's unique i-number.

The user's unique i-name.

The airport code of the user's region.

The user's status.

A boolean which indicates if the user is locked.

A boolean which indicates if the user has been soft deleted.

The user's country.

The user's time zone.

A user's api key.

A user's password.

The UserStatus indicates whether the user is active or inactive

The user is Active and can authenticate with the Idm API.

The user is Inactive and cannot authenticate with the Idm API.

Clients

This schema file defines entities related to roles.

A role.

A list of roles.

The list of permissions associated with the role.

The name of the role.

The role type.

Clients

This schema file defines entities related to permissions.

A permission.

A list of permissions.

A id of a permission.

The customerId that owns the clientId.

The mime type of the permission.

Clients

This schema file defines entities related to a client.

A rackspace client.

A list of rackspace clients.

A rackspace client's credentials.

The client's credentials.

A list of permissions the client has.

The client's unique Id.

The unique Id for the customer the client belongs to.

The client name.

The client's unique i-number.

The client's unique i-name.

The user's status.

A boolean which indicates if the client is locked.

A boolean which indicates if the client has been soft deleted.

A client's secret.

The ClientStatus indicates whether the user is active or inactive

The client is Active and can authenticate with the Idm API.

The client is Inactive and cannot authenticate with the Idm API.

API Version Details

This schema file defines a version element which provides meta information about the current version of the API.

This element provides detailed meta information regarding the status of the API version. Included is a pointer to both a human readable and a machine processable description of the API service. The machine processable description is written in the Web Application Description Language (WADL). If a discrepancy exists between the two specifications, the WADL is authoritative as it contains the most accurate and up-to-date description of the API service.

A unique ID which identifies the API version. Currently this is fixed as v1.0 . The first element of the path to the API endpoints always contains the target version ID.

The status of the API version. A stable version will always have the value CURRENT . See VersionStatus .

A URL to a human readable API specification in PDF format. This URL will always point to the latest version of the specification applicable to the requested implementation.

A URL to a machine readable API specification in WADL format. This URL will always point to the latest version of the specification applicable to the requested implementation.

A status of BETA indicates that this version is a candidate for the next major release and may feature functionality not available in the current version. Developers are encouraged to test and begin the migration processes to a BETA version. Note that a BETA version is undergoing testing, it has not been officially released, and my not be stable.

The API version is stable and has been tested. Developers are encouraged to develop against this API version. The current released version of the API will always be marked as CURRENT.

A status of DEPRECATED indicates that a newer version of the API is available. Application developers are discouraged from using this version and should instead develop against the latest current version of the API.

Customers

This schema file defines entities related to a customer.

A rackspace customer.

A list of rackspace customers.

A unique customer Id. This is also known as the customer number.

A unique inum associated with the customer.

A unique iname associated with the customer inum.

A boolean indicating if the customer is locked.

A boolean indicating if the customer has been soft deleted.

Passwords

This schema file defines entities related to a password.

A password rule.

A list of password rules.

A password validation.

A password rule result.

A list of password rule results.

A unique Id for the password rule.

The name of the password rule.

A human readable description of the rule.

A boolean which indicates whether the password passed the rule.

A unique Id for the password rule.

The name of the password rule.

A human readable description of the rule.

A boolean which indicates whether the password passed all rules.

Faults

This schema file defines faults that may be raised by the IdM API. These faults are derived from the IdmFault

Faults are associated with a default HTTP status code that corresponds to the particular fault type. For example an <itemNotFound> element is associated with the HTTP status code 404. Some elements, the <idmFault> element for example, may be associated with multiple status codes. It is also possible for multiple fault elements to be associated with the same default code. The examples below showcase the default status codes for each element type. Note that these default codes are not part of the formal schema. In practice, however, an element type will likely be associated with its corresponding default status code.

A generic Idm Fault.

The user has been disabled and is not permitted to authenticate.

An authentication request requires a username.

The request is malformed.

Authorization failed. Bad API Key? Username?

The item or resource could not be found.

Authentication succeeded but you lack sufficient privileges.

A user with that username already exists.

A client with that clientname already exists.

A permisssion with that Id already exists.

A user with that email address already exists.

A customer with that customerId already exists.

The API is currently unavailable.

The password failed validation.

The method is not allowed on the resource.

An erorr occured on the server.

A human readable message that is appropriate for display to the end user.

The optional <details> element may contain useful information for tracking down errors (e.g a stack trace). This information may or may not be appropriate for display to an end user.

The HTTP status code associated with the current fault.

Password Recovery

Parameters for password recovery email. Allows for client-specified named parameters that will be substituted into placeholders in email template.

 Client-specified named parameter. The parameter names are arbitrary and irrelevant to the IDM system itself, other than the matching placeholders in email template will be substituted with the value of the incoming named parameters.

A password recovery object.

Idm API Schema Types

This is the main index XML Schema document for the Rackspace Identity Management API.

Entities related to backwards compatible auth.

Entities related to backwards compatible auth endpoints.

Entities related to IdM permissions.

Entities related to IdM roles.

Entities related to API version details.

User entities.

Client entities.

Customer entities.

Defines credentials used to obtain an OAuth token.

Password entities.

All fault types.

End user password recovery request..

Credentials

This schema file defines entities credentials used to obtained a token from the authentication service.

Credentials used to obtain an auth token.

Nast Credentials.

Mosso Credentials.

The API key.

The name of the user authenticated.

Nast Id used to identify the user.

Mosso account used to identify the user.

An Auth Token.

The service catalog.

A combination of the token and the service catalog. This is returned when a user authenticates.

BaseUrls and Endpoints

The service catalog contains a list of all regional and global endpoints available to a user. The endpoints are sorted by service type.

A list of services.

A list of endpoints.

The service name.

The airport code of the region where the endpoint lives.

If true, then the endpoint will be selected automatically in V1.0 of the Auth API.

The publically accessible service URL.

A service URL, accessible only within the Rackspace Cloud.

A service URL used for administration. This may expose additional functionality not found in the public and internal URL.

A list of base URLs.

A base URLs.

A refrence to a base URL.

A list of base URL refrences.

An ID uniquely identifying the base URL.

What type of user information should be appended to this baseURL to form a complete endpoint.

The base URL's service name.

The URL's region.

The public base URL.

The internal version of the public base URL.

The admin base URL.

If true the baseURL is automatically added to new accounts.

An ID uniquely identifying the base URL.

A hyperlink refrence to the base URL.

If true, then the refred to base URL is used in version 1.0 of the Auth service.

An authRequest can be made with various user/account names. The UserType signifies what kind of account is being used to log in.

Cloud username. This is the same as the unique user id in the UserType.

Nast account number. This is the same as a nastId in the UserType.

Mosso account number. This is the same as mossoId in the UserType.

Tokens

This schema file defines entities related to tokens.

Entities related users.

Entities related to clients.

Entities related to permissions.

The data returned for a successful authentication.

The data required for authentication.

An authentication Token.

The token id.

A number of seconds until the token expires.

An access token.

A refresh token.

The user associated with the token.

A client associated with the token.

The OAuth grant type.

The client Id.

The client secret.

The user's username.

The user's password.

The refresh token Id.

The OAuth grant type api_credentials.

The OAuth grant type assertion.

The OAuth grant type authorization_code.

The OAuth grant type none.

The OAuth grant type password.

The OAuth grant type refresh_token.

Users

This schema file defines entities related to a user.

A rackspace user's credentials.

A rackspace user's api key.

A rackspace user's password.

A rackspace user.

A list of rackspace users.

A rackspace user's secret question and answer.

The user's new password.

The user's current password.

A user's secret question.

The answer to the user's secret question.

The user's secret contains a question and answer that can be used to confirm the user's identity.

A user's password.

A user's api key.

A list of roles the user belongs to.

The unique username of the user.

The customerId of the customer that the user is associated with.

The customer inum of the customer that the user is associated with.

The user's email address.

A unique rackspace personId for the user.

The user's first name.

The user's middle name.

The user's last name.

The user's display name.

The user's preferred language.

The user's unique i-number.

The user's unique i-name.

The airport code of the user's region.

The user's status.

A boolean which indicates if the user is locked.

A boolean which indicates if the user has been soft deleted.

The user's country.

The user's time zone.

A user's api key.

A user's password.

The UserStatus indicates whether the user is active or inactive

The user is Active and can authenticate with the Idm API.

The user is Inactive and cannot authenticate with the Idm API.

Clients

This schema file defines entities related to a client.

A rackspace client.

A list of rackspace clients.

A rackspace client's credentials.

The client's credentials.

A list of permissions the client has.

The client's unique Id.

The unique Id for the customer the client belongs to.

The client name.

The client's unique i-number.

The client's unique i-name.

The user's status.

A boolean which indicates if the client is locked.

A boolean which indicates if the client has been soft deleted.

A client's secret.

The ClientStatus indicates whether the user is active or inactive

The client is Active and can authenticate with the Idm API.

The client is Inactive and cannot authenticate with the Idm API.

Clients

This schema file defines entities related to permissions.

A permission.

A list of permissions.

A id of a permission.

The customerId that owns the clientId.

The clientId that owns the permission.

The mime type of the permission.

Clients

This schema file defines entities related to roles.

A role.

A list of roles.

The list of permissions associated with the role.

The name of the role.

The role type.

API Version Details

This schema file defines a version element which provides meta information about the current version of the API.

This element provides detailed meta information regarding the status of the API version. Included is a pointer to both a human readable and a machine processable description of the API service. The machine processable description is written in the Web Application Description Language (WADL). If a discrepancy exists between the two specifications, the WADL is authoritative as it contains the most accurate and up-to-date description of the API service.

A unique ID which identifies the API version. Currently this is fixed as v1.0 . The first element of the path to the API endpoints always contains the target version ID.

The status of the API version. A stable version will always have the value CURRENT . See VersionStatus .

A URL to a human readable API specification in PDF format. This URL will always point to the latest version of the specification applicable to the requested implementation.

A URL to a machine readable API specification in WADL format. This URL will always point to the latest version of the specification applicable to the requested implementation.

A status of BETA indicates that this version is a candidate for the next major release and may feature functionality not available in the current version. Developers are encouraged to test and begin the migration processes to a BETA version. Note that a BETA version is undergoing testing, it has not been officially released, and my not be stable.

The API version is stable and has been tested. Developers are encouraged to develop against this API version. The current released version of the API will always be marked as CURRENT.

A status of DEPRECATED indicates that a newer version of the API is available. Application developers are discouraged from using this version and should instead develop against the latest current version of the API.

Customers

This schema file defines entities related to a customer.

A rackspace customer.

A list of rackspace customers.

A unique customer Id. This is also known as the customer number.

A unique inum associated with the customer.

A unique iname associated with the customer inum.

A boolean indicating if the customer is locked.

A boolean indicating if the customer has been soft deleted.

Passwords

This schema file defines entities related to a password.

A password rule.

A list of password rules.

A password validation.

A password rule result.

A list of password rule results.

A unique Id for the password rule.

The name of the password rule.

A human readable description of the rule.

A boolean which indicates whether the password passed the rule.

A unique Id for the password rule.

The name of the password rule.

A human readable description of the rule.

A boolean which indicates whether the password passed all rules.

Faults

This schema file defines faults that may be raised by the IdM API. These faults are derived from the IdmFault

Faults are associated with a default HTTP status code that corresponds to the particular fault type. For example an <itemNotFound> element is associated with the HTTP status code 404. Some elements, the <idmFault> element for example, may be associated with multiple status codes. It is also possible for multiple fault elements to be associated with the same default code. The examples below showcase the default status codes for each element type. Note that these default codes are not part of the formal schema. In practice, however, an element type will likely be associated with its corresponding default status code.

A generic Idm Fault.

The user has been disabled and is not permitted to authenticate.

An authentication request requires a username.

The request is malformed.

Authorization failed. Bad API Key? Username?

The item or resource could not be found.

Authentication succeeded but you lack sufficient privileges.

A user with that username already exists.

A client with that clientname already exists.

A permisssion with that Id already exists.

A user with that email address already exists.

A customer with that customerId already exists.

A baseUrl with that id already exists.

A client group with that name already exists.

The API is currently unavailable.

The password failed validation.

User or admin attempted to update his/her own password more than once in the 24-hour period since the last self-update.

The password failed validation.

The method is not allowed on the resource.

An erorr occured on the server.

A human readable message that is appropriate for display to the end user.

The optional <details> element may contain useful information for tracking down errors (e.g a stack trace). This information may or may not be appropriate for display to an end user.

The HTTP status code associated with the current fault.

Password Recovery

Parameters for password recovery email. Allows for client-specified named parameters that will be substituted into placeholders in email template.

 Client-specified named parameter. The parameter names are arbitrary and irrelevant to the IDM system itself, other than the matching placeholders in email template will be substituted with the value of the incoming named parameters.

A password recovery object.
